Posted: October 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								Kickstarter promise: A Real Time Strategy God Game for PC, a sequel to the Populous franchise.What we are getting: A mobile click fest with build timers, like Farmville. An ordinary mobile game on PC.I'm writing this while still on Beta. This is not what we have been promised on Kickstart. Being scammed by Peter Molyneux, is like being r@ped by Mozart or Picasso: you keep denying it because it felt good helping someone famous getting what they wanted, but it's still a serious r@ping and you know you'll never walk straight again.Can I ask my money back? No. Can I delete this from my Steam Library? No. Can you help me forget this? No. Can it become a good game? Of course. I'll change this review, if it becomes a decent game after the Beta. Chances? Low. Very low. These people strike us as very arrogant, they will not take a step back and check out the big picture, the deviation from their Kickstarter promise.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								This isn't the regenesis of the God-sim game. It is a mobile game masquerading as something more. The game is an endless clickfest that far removes you from the very idea of being a deity. Mana is manually gathered & "upgrades" are unlocked by digging up chests of stickers to stick on upgrade cards. The game pace is very slow, with mana & grain accumulation creeping up whilst you sit looking at a very sterile world environment, waiting for timegates on shrines or houses to complete. Your god powers are very limited for much of the early game - allowing you to do little more than push around ground or set out settlements (at great expense).Avoid. If you want a good recent godsim, get From Dust. If you want a better mobile game, try Plague Inc or the Kim Kardashian thing.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								you may not take this review too serious as i'm actually not that much into these kind of gamesanywaygodus, you're a god and you save 2 people who then become your followers and they worship you and you help them start up a civilizationnow everything goes pretty slow at the start, which they pretty much tell you as well, because you gotta start building buildings and get your population up and junk (the bigger the houses get, the more minutes it takes)it's kind of tedious but manageable (though a little bit boring)the bigger your population, the more things you unlock yada yadaanyway at some point it basically became a waiting game, but they tell you it doesn't have to be because at this point you unlocked a few things which you can play (sort of like some kind of puzzle mini-game which gets you rewards) and you can do that while they're buildingwhich would have been great if it wasn't for the fact that after the tutorial it sorta broke on me, but i guess that's just me maybe, so i actually had to sit everything outso you figure do some land shaping instead so you have more places to build or you're able to have better acces to some places, well that's also quite a thing,,,,it might just be me but whenever i try to reform land or drag anything it doesn't really do it the way i want it to and sometimes it just pulls back altogether, or it grabs another patch and it's justreally reallytiringi think that would be the most frustrating thing about this entire game really, and it's pretty big part as well because you actually kinda gotta do it a lot to get further or your followers won't be able to go to new placesand also, there's these pink orbs that basically make everything possible for you, when you try to reform the land it will cost these orbs but also using your powers cost these orbs, so if you run outit's basically a waiting game again (at least for me because i couldn't use the dock)honestly this game involved so much waiting for me which is why i actually just left it on while eating dinneri think it's a great game (maybe?) if you have something else to do while playing or if the dock worked (also the music is kind of nice when it's there, finding chests is sorta creepy though?)but if you're not really into the build a population and you better have an endless amount of patience thing, then i wouldn't recommend it (i also wouldn't recommend it if the reforming the land part ticks you off as it doesn't work all that well, because it only gets worse)

Early Access Review
								What started out as an exciting new labor of love from the famous Peter Molyneux has slowly turned into a small gasp which has many wondering if we will ever see what was ultimately promised. Slow development, little communication from the developers, and rumors that 22Cans is running out of money are what fans are currently experiencing. All this plus the fact that the current state of the game simplifies down to just endless and repetitive mouse clicking. If you are one of the customers who spent the 20.00 to become part or Early Access you have reason to a bit concerned.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game has immense potential but requires drastic change before I can consider recommending it.  As many others have said, Godus involves a mind-numbing amount of clicking and not much else.  Some changes the developers have made thus far have actually been harmful.  THe control scheme needs to be overhauled, and any micro-transaction systems that do or may exist need to be omitted entirely.  Different locations or procedurally-generated maps would help immensely, because every game I've seen played ends up essentially the same.  Could be good, but only after some much-needed improvements.  Don't buy unless marked down.

content:

Early Access Review
								Fun at first, with the promise of more to come. Unfortunately this game has been updated and modified time and time again. With each update, this game has become less and less promising.  All of the updates seem very superficial and designed to hide the fact that the game at it's core is very shallow. Click this to make the ground go down..... use this power to click faster and make the ground go more down. In it's current state of decline I cannot recommend Godus to anyone. If you have any interest in Godus don't buy it on steam, download it on the app store for free and tap away to your hearts content.

								There was a time when I would have recommended this game to the moon and back- but not anymore.22cans has all but abandoned it in favour of their mobile game. You'll get maybe 15 hours out of it, if you're patient, before you find nothing new happens and you have too much currency and nothing to spend it on. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								Kickstarter promise: A Real Time Strategy God Game for PC, a sequel to the Populous franchise.What we are getting: A mobile click fest with build timers, like Farmville. An ordinary mobile game on PC.I'm writing this while still on Beta. This is not what we have been promised on Kickstart. Being scammed by Peter Molyneux, is like being r@ped by Mozart or Picasso: you keep denying it because it felt good helping someone famous getting what they wanted, but it's still a serious r@ping and you know you'll never walk straight again.Can I ask my money back? No. Can I delete this from my Steam Library? No. Can you help me forget this? No. Can it become a good game? Of course. I'll change this review, if it becomes a decent game after the Beta. Chances? Low. Very low. These people strike us as very arrogant, they will not take a step back and check out the big picture, the deviation from their Kickstarter promise.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Massively disappointed with this and the direction it's continuing to take.  I went Kickstarter on this off the strength of Peter Molyneux's name, having loved classics like Dungeon Keeper.The two biggest problems I have with this game are:1)  The concept of having to manually collect the mana bubbles (called 'Belief' in this game).  It was made minutely more bearable by the introduction of the "swishy" grab, but having to manually scroll around and do it at all is trash and utterly unfun.  Very surprised that anyone in 22 Cans thinks this is fun... well maybe the accountant does....2)  The pace - it is torurously slow.  Any modicum of fun that was left after having to collect the belief bubbles, is removed after trying to deal with the painfully slow pace.Extremely disappointed to say the least - really was expecting a gem from something with Peter's involvement and guidance.  It feels like those of us that ran with the idea on Kickstarter / early access have just been used so that they can churn out a game that looks more like it's been designed to milk micro-transactions as a "F2P".  :(

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								Avoid at all cost!After one and a half hours, all I've managed to do is deforest and flatten what was once a beautiful, wooded hillside, bust some rocks and watch little stick figures run around randomly building offensively ugly ... houses, I guess, for want of a better word. They look like blocks of concrete, instead of the tent and wood structures one would expect of this time period and they all look basically identical. Oh, and the stick figures died rather frequently while trying to crawl up a mountain I hadn't flattened completely ...I have never before encountered a game, where everything you have to do in order to proceed makes the game look much, much uglier than it was before. There is no apparent end in sight for the devastation one has to wreak upon the landscape, and the final straw for me after entering the game again after a couple of days, is the ridiculous amount of clicking I have to do just to collect the belief of my followers - like some beggar on the street knocking on every door, rather than the god I am supposed to be.Did I mention how ugly you have to make the landscape in order to proceed? I have no idea how long it takes to be able to make the towns look as pretty as they do in some of the screenshots with buildings surrounded by trees, but I simply don't have the energy or the patience to find out.I made the mistake of buying this while it was 50% off, but if there was any way I could get my money and time back I would be a much happier individual.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								In its current state, Godus feels like nothing more than a half baked farmville game.The previews promise something great and unique, but at the moment. You're looking at grinding for 20 hours making the exact same houses, exact same hovels with slight upgrades that give you more belief. All the while getting slightly better houses. The people in your world do not roam around freely, you simply pop them out of their hovels when you need them to build more houses. Then when you get settlements, random villagers that you can't interact with in any way spawn and walk around aimlessly to 'total simulation'.Even SimCity has more complex and interesting simulation than this game in it's current state. There's just absolutely nothing to do in a barren completely non randomly generated homeworld. Except poke wolves without any animations-great. Maybe it will be an amazing game at some point. But unless you like the prospect of carpal tunnel syndrome and constant non-smooth 'land sculpting'. Avoid it for now.

								This game has come a long way since the first early access release.  However, it is still nothing like I expected.  If you are looking for something like Black and White you will be very disappointed.  The game can't decide whether it is a city builder or a god game.  It is simply mediocre at both.  Frankly, this game falls flat on its face.  I keep trying each new build expecting the devs to listen to player criticisms and make meaningful changes, but this has been half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥so far.  Hopefully it gets better over time.  Example of why this game is ♥♥♥♥♥♥ thus far:  I had to leave my game on and go do laundry and clean my house to wait for belief to accumulate.  Thanks Peter.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Godus could have been a good game, Godus had potential, Godus seemed like a great idea then once again Peter Molineux screwed us over and wasted the crowdfunded money quickly. I was hoping overtime that this game would grow to be a great mix between Civilisation and From Dust (the world manipulation) but unfortunately I don't think that will ever happen. It's not the developers fault as they still work on this pile of crap trying to eventually make it good but I will never forgive how he lied to the backers (me included) as well as all his other buyers and the guy that was meant to get a percentage of the earnings (who hasn't been spoken to in ages cause the guy in charge of it was sacked). So buy this game if you must but remember you are buying a game that is unfinished and probably never will be, you can get it for FREE on mobile and you are fighting for a lost causeRIP Godusyou could have been great

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								Currently in beta, Godus boasts a very stylized and fun looking environment that has a surprisingly large amount of player interaction. The positive aspects stop there unfortunately. This game seems to have the ambition being the next Black and White, perfect for people who have a god complex and enoy city builders, but it is anything but. Already a year into beta, few things have changed in terms of gameplay. It is overly simplistic, repetitive, and linear, hardly the attributes one would want in a game of this genre. Godus is a games of could-bes, it has all of the potential of being something great, however it has a long way to go.
